column68: Other
column69: Imposition of P&M by UoE central admin without consultation with lab based researchers was highly disruptive to research and an example of mismanagement. It has created a huge barrier and is an example of how gross stupidly increases the workload for researchers. Very poor with respect to our research culture. Anothe example is the imposition of Diversity Travel as our sole Travel Agency - limiting choice to a single supplier stifles competition and consequently we pay more from our hard won grants to travel to conferences. Very poor policy from a research culture perspective.
column88: The recent imposed freeze for 6 weeks on ordering while the ridiculously cumbersome P&M system was installed without sufficient beta testing or allowing the old system to operate in tandem was and remains an example of institutional bullying which is totally at odds with the provision of a good research culture. The enforced use of Diversity Travel (laughable name given we have no choice) as our sole supplier is another example of institutional bullying and poor consultation with grant holders in our research community. University SLT/admin are here to SERVE researchers not to HINDER their research by implementing systems that increase their workload and excessively restrict how they operate
column91: Institutional bullying as exemplified by how the not fit for purpose P&M and Diversity Travel/Sustainable Travel Policies have been imposed on researchers without sufficient (any?) consultation
column132: I feel stretched but it's manageable

column69: I would like to continue to do research in the formal context of the University just as others professionally volunteer in other charitable instutions, with appropriate constraints and oversight, just as Prof Andrew Morris's father does at Haddington CAB though he is over 90!. He contributes significantly and also mentors new recruits. He aalso gains from being in a recognised active role interacting with colleagues. I believe the UoE, being a charitable organisation, as more of age with good capabilities  w should, filtered by appropriate and periodic selection and retraining procedures, contribute to the UoE's research culture. I know many who are carrying on aspects of research, but not contributing to, nor being supported by the UoE's research culture.

column69: Systems are all set up for a very linear career progression for PhD to postdoc to fellowship to lectureship. I'm permanent teaching staff, but am publishing and doing bit of predominantly computational research and supervising students, and the system finds me a complete oddity. More support for teaching staff doing small amounts of research (but who don't want to be full time researchers) would make a big difference not just to people like me but clinicians etc too who are heavily involved in teaching.
